page.title: 02LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS
page.content: For gently rolling country in a region of intensive agriculture the area surveyed has suffered surprisingly little from hedge removal. Hedges are nowhere high, three to five feet is typical, but they still divide fields as well as forming road boundaries. Stanhoe has lost many large elms but other trees have been planted to replace them notably around the village pond (correctly East Mere) where an effort has been made to use only native shrubs and trees. The local building material is flint, and this together with red brick corners and pantiles gives a distinctive colouring to the village. The largest secular building is a fine red brick barn of the 1720s still in active use and housing a corn dryer. Stanhoe Hall of 1702 is a lovely red brick house designed by Henry Bell of Lynn.
